coredata.dc:title: An extended X-Ray absorption fine structure (exafs) study of copper (II) sulphate pentahydrate
coredata.dc:creator: Joyner, Richard W.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The EXAFS spectrum of copper (II) sulphate pentahydrate has been measured using synchrotron radiation. Comparison with the results of ab initio calculation gives a mean copper-oxygen distance of 1.95 Å, in reasonable agreement with the known value of 1.97 Å. The relation between the EXAFS Debye-Waller factor and thermal parameters measured by neutron diffraction is discussed. Absence in the EXAFS spectrum of evidence for the second-nearest neighbour oxygen atoms, at Cu-O ≈ 2.4 Å, is discussed.

This letter gives experimental data and the results of an ab initio calculation for the copper K shell EXAFS of copper (II) sulphate pentahydrate. In this compound copper is surrounded by a tetragonally dis- torted octahedron of oxygen atoms [3,4] and the crys- tal structure is of low symmetry, being tnchnic. Martens et al [5] studied the EXAFS of this com- pound using a rotating anode source. For the transform and the EXAFS calculation described below, the absorption edge was located 14 eV below the position of the experimental edge. This position is thought likely to correspond more accurately to the muffin-tin zero, which is the appropriate energy zero; calculations by Martens et al. [5], suggest a similar position for the energy origin of the EXAFS spectrum. In agreement with Martens et al. [5], the transform shows only a single major peak. This peak is much nar- rower than that observed by Martens et al., reflecting the greater energy range and lower noise level of the synchrotron-generated data. The peak position, at 1.57 A, is at longer Cu 0 distance than reported pre- viously, 1.46 A. Since the energy origin and gaussian window are similar to those used by Martens et al., this substantial shift reflects the use of data extending over a greater energy range. Reasonable variation of the energy origin and of the gaussian window function caused shifts in the position of the Fourier transform maximum of < 0.05 A. We now describe the calculation of the EXAFS spectrum. The domination of the Fourier transform by a single peak shows that only a single shell of neigh- bouring atoms contributes substantially. We have there- fore considered copper surrounded by four equidis- tant oxygen atoms in a square-planar array, although recognizing that the geometrical arrangement of the backscattering atoms is of no importance for a poly- crystalline sample. The phase shifts were calculated in the local density approximation. The charge density was constructed with overlapping atomic charges, using Hartree Fock wavefunctions due to Clementi [7]. Copper was octahedrally coordinated to oxygen in the calculation of the phase shifts. In the EXAFS calculation the Cu 0 distance and the Debye Waller factor were treated as parameters and the imaginary part of the self-energy was set to 4 eV.
